awd_titl_txt: Compliance and Dynamic Geometry Variation in Coronory Artery Flows under In-Vivo Conditions
awd_abstract_narration:
1235790
Tafti

Cardiovascular diseases (CVD) are the number one causes of death in the world. Extensive research has shown that arterial wall mechanics and fluid dynamics play an important role in CVD mediation. As the heart beats, the coronary arteries (CA), which are attached to the pericardial surface or penetrate the myocardial wall, also experience substantial motion. This motion is large scale and three dimensional in nature, with local changes in curvature and torsion of the vessel. The effect of this motion on the fluid dynamics of blood flow is further complicated by variations in arterial wall stiffness resulting from plaque formation (atherosclerosis) or the placement of stents. The research is driven by the hypothesis that in CA flows, the large scale motions due to the motion of the myocardium along with local variations or discontinuities of the vessel stiffness lead to non-physiological flow patterns and abnormal wall shear stresses triggering atherosclerosis.  In order to tackle the scientific and engineering challenges imposed, we will use state-of-art highly-resolved computations to create a unique research framework that will significantly augment our understanding of these complex flow systems.  Using computational modeling of fully resolved fluid-structure-interaction (FSI), the computations will tackle with unprecedented fidelity the unsteady coupled fluid structure interactions with applied motion of the myocardium and the arterial flow characteristics that have challenged researchers in the past. Resolving the physical mechanisms of FSI in flexible vessels with anisotropic compliance under the influence of the myocardial motion as experienced in coronary arteries will lead to new understanding of transport processes in physiological systems. The research grant will train one graduate student and provide research experience to a number of undergraduate students. A number of initiatives will be undertaken to involve women and minorities in research and education, and to foster research partnerships with medical institutions. The proposed research will contribute towards better diagnosis of vascular disease and will have broad ranging implications on the management of cardio-vascular disease with the potential of saving millions of lives. It will provide the foundation needed for analyzing and improving vascular implants as well as enable the development of new and improved treatments and devices.

por.por_cntn:
According to the World Health Organization (WHO), Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death in the world. Arterial wall mechanics and fluid dynamics of blood flow play an important role in CVD mediation. The research concerns itself with two aspects of CVD, the first of which leads to the production of abnormal blood flow in the vessel and secondly the response of the vessel to the abnormal conditions which lead to further abnormalities developing in the vessel by way of thrombus formation. As the heart beats, the coronary arteries (CA), which are attached to the pericardial surface or penetrate the myocardial wall, also experience substantial motion. This motion is large scale and three dimensional in nature with local changes in the curvature and twist of the vessel. The effect of vessel geometry and motion on blood flow is complicated by variations in arterial wall stiffness resulting from thrombus formation (atherosclerosis) or the placement of stents. Stented sections increase stiffness, and combined with the geometry and the motion of the artery, impact the fluid stresses felt by the vessel wall. One objective of the current work was to understand the effect of a smoother and longer transition from the highly stiff stent to the lower stiffness of the blood vessel, the stent length, and the use of a stent of diameter larger than the vessel diameter (overexpansion) on the creation or mitigation of abnormal fluid stresses. The key outcome from this study was that decreasing transition length, increasing stent length, and increasing the overexpansion would affect the local hemodynamics adversely and lead to higher variations in wall shear stress. This has significance on the clinical practices followed during stent deployment.

The abnormal stress conditions in turn elicit a defensive response by way of platelet activation and deposition.  There are billions of free flowing benign platelets in blood under normal conditions. However, under abnormal conditions, the platelets get “activated” and flow to the vessel wall and deposit. On deposition they secrete antagonists which lead to more platelets getting activated. The platelets depositing on the wall lead to the formation of thrombi or obstructions which increase the fluid stresses, leading to more platelets being activated, starting a destructive chain reaction which leads to stenosis and in extreme condition to the dislodging of plaque emboli which can cause strokes.   The major etiology of arterial malfunctions is therefore platelet-rich thrombosis. It is well established that changes in flow characteristics, hence shear conditions can significantly affect the platelet deposition evolution in arterial flows. Shear effects along with physio-chemical reactions contribute to the platelet deposition process in a synergic manner. In particular, the current work has emphasized on effects of shear stress on chemical interactions between blood/tissue components involved in atherogenesis and thrombus formation, unlike previous computational models in the literature in which some parts of these two major effects were missing. It was shown that the platelet adhesion is not only a function of Reynolds number (or wall shear rate) but also the stenosis severity of the vessel. Correlating the platelet adhesion to these two parameters provided a better outcome in terms of deposition prediction in stenotic flows under in-vitro and ex-vivo conditions.

Two PhD students worked on this project over a period of four-five years gaining valuable training in bioengineering and computational methods. Naresh Selvarasu is currently an engineer at ANSYS-Fluent with expertise in fluid-structure interaction, which he gained during his Ph.D. Hamid Hosseinzadegan is still continuing with this research and should complete his PhD in 2017. The results have been disseminated to the larger community of researchers through two journal papers and one conference paper and it is anticipated that at least two additional journal papers will be published in the coming months, one of which is under review. The project was also successful in initiating collaborations with Prof. Bahareh Behkam in Mechanical Engineering at VT and with Prof. Scott Verbridge at the VT-Carilion Research Institute.
